content:
I have given AutoGpt commands to write Lean 4 code ( GPT-3.5 Turbo, don't have access to GPT-4)
For hello world program it have given output : def main : IO Unit := print "Hello, World!"
Now I have given command to prove Liquid Tensor Theorem ( I know this is a bad idea ), just to check what output it can give .
It is looking into entire history of Lean and Lean 4, still running for 30 min, it haven't got into theory of Liquid Tensor Experiment.
I hope it dose it's own research and do not copy from existing solution...

Looks like it is gonna take days if not weeks. :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:

Sample
image.png
I am gonna keep it running for some time.

Message I got from another heggingface model "I now know that Lean 4 currently lacks the mathematical infrastructure needed for the Liquid Tensor Experiment, but there are plans to add it in the future. However, it is not clear when this will happen."

Is it true ?? Dose Lean 4 lack infra for Liquid Tensor Experiment ??
Sure, the port from Lean 3 to Lean 4 is still ongoing, and I'm virtually certain LTE uses things that haven't been ported yet.

Now I have given command to prove Liquid Tensor Theorem ( I know this is a bad idea ), just to check what output it can give .

What's the exact goal you gave it? I don't think the main theorem in LTE is called LTT?

Personally I haven't set up AutoGPT locally but tested some online demos; https://www.aomni.com/ seems the most impressive (no need of API key, can browse Internet). Here is the output from my standard Riemann hypothesis test: https://www.aomni.com/search/ac200c1b-fed3-4ecf-b2b9-9adde489cbb8 Pretty good summary of the most recent progress I'd say. The other goal I like to set is "Find out the status of Yitang Zhang's paper "Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero"." I tried it a few days ago, but the system seems to become more powerful in the meantime (at least the format of Progress greatly improved). No agent has been able to find this recent talk so far. (Of course we can't expect it to watch the video but it may be able to extract transcripts from the page ...)

https://agentgpt.reworkd.ai/ is other free option, but lacks Internet access so it's mostly just hallucinating. https://godmode.space/ and https://beta.nando.ai/goalgpt.php are options that require OpennAI API key. (Edit: oh the latter actually doesn't require a key, but the output makes little sense ...)
(Edit 2: https://www.cognosys.ai/create is yet another free option and there's a button to allow Internet browsing.)

Junyan Xu said:

Now I have given command to prove Liquid Tensor Theorem ( I know this is a bad idea ), just to check what output it can give .

What's the exact goal you gave it? I don't think the main theorem in LTE is called LTT?

Personally I haven't set up AutoGPT locally but tested some online demos; https://www.aomni.com/ seems the most impressive (no need of API key, can browse Internet). Here is the output from my standard Riemann hypothesis test: https://www.aomni.com/search/ac200c1b-fed3-4ecf-b2b9-9adde489cbb8 Pretty good summary of the most recent progress I'd say. The other goal I like to set is "Find out the status of Yitang Zhang's paper "Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero"." I tried it a few days ago, but the system seems to become more powerful in the meantime (at least the format of Progress greatly improved). No agent has been able to find this recent talk so far.

https://agentgpt.reworkd.ai/ is the other free option, but lacks Internet access so it's mostly just hallucinating. https://godmode.space/ and https://beta.nando.ai/goalgpt.php are options that require OpennAI API key. (Edit: oh the latter actually doesn't require a key, now testing ...)

I had given it goal as "Prove Liquid Tensor Experiment in Lean 4" ... I want to get it's code. Currently using https://autogptjs.com/
( req api key ) . Tried for hello world . It created hello_world.lean file on my system . As Liquid Tensor Experiment have prof in Lean 3 , so I tried it on lean 4.

As for
" Find out the status of Yitang Zhang's paper "Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero".
on https://autogptjs.com/

I got answer as follows

The paper titled "Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero" by Yitang Zhang has been submitted to the arXiv and is available to download. The paper proves a lower bound for L(1,χ), where χ is a real primitive character to the modulus D, showing that L(1,χ)≥(log D)^-2022 with an absolute and computable constant. The proof involves evaluating discrete means of the large sieve type and deriving results on the distribution of zeros of a family of Dirichlet L-functions.

Method 2: Bing Chat on microsoft edge browser ( Uses GPT-4 in constrained way ) I got answers as follows

Q. Find out the status of Yitang Zhang's paper "Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero".
Answer :
The paper “Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero” by Yitang Zhang is a preprint that was submitted to arXiv on 4 Nov 202212. It claims to prove the Landau-Siegel zeros conjecture, which is a long-standing problem in number theory related to the distribution of zeros of Dirichlet L-functions13. The paper is 111 pages long and consists of 18 sections45. It has not been peer-reviewed or published in a journal yet, so its validity and impact are still uncertain.

Q. search latest update on it and explaine in detaile
Answer :
According to the search results, there is no official update on the paper since it was submitted to arXiv on 4 Nov 2022¹²⁴. However, some news articles and online discussions have reported on the paper and its significance³⁵. Here is a brief summary of the paper and its main idea:

The paper aims to prove the Landau-Siegel zeros conjecture, which states that for any real primitive character χ to the modulus D, the Dirichlet L-function L(s, χ) does not vanish near s = 1, except possibly at a single real zero ρ satisfying |ρ - 1| < c0(log D)^-1 for some absolute constant c0. This conjecture is one of the major open problems in analytic number theory, as it has implications for the distribution of prime numbers, the class number problem for imaginary quadratic fields, and the abc conjecture.

The main result of the paper is that for any real primitive character χ to the modulus D, L(1, χ) > c1(log D)^-2022 for some absolute and effectively computable constant c1. This implies that L(s, χ) does not vanish for s > 1 - c2(log D)^-2024 for some absolute and effectively computable constant c2. This result improves on the previous best known bound of L(1, χ) > C1(ε)D^-ε for any ε > 0 by Siegel, which was ineffective and did not rule out the possibility of a Landau-Siegel zero.

The main idea of the proof is to relate the lower bound for L(1, χ) to the distribution of zeros of a family of Dirichlet L-functions L(s, ψχ) in a certain region Ω, where ψ runs over a set of characters Ψ1. The author uses some results on the gaps between consecutive zeros of L(s, ψχ) to show that if L(1, χ) is too small, then there are too many zeros in Ω. Then, by evaluating certain discrete means of the large sieve type involving ψ and χ, the author obtains a contradiction. The proof involves many technical lemmas and calculations involving Euler products, arithmetic sums, and complex analysis.

Source: Conversation with Bing, 26/4/2023
(1) [2211.02515] Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero. https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.02515.
(2) Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero. https://arxiv-export1.library.cornell.edu/pdf/2211.02515.
(3) Title: Discrete mean estimates and the Landau-Siegel zero. https://arxiv-export1.library.cornell.edu/abs/2211.02515.
(4) Chinese-American Mathematician Yitang Zhang Publishes Paper on Landau .... https://pandaily.com/chinese-american-mathematician-yitang-zhang-publishes-paper-on-landau-siegel-zeros-conjecture/.
(5) Philosophy behind Zhang's 2022 preprint on the Landau–Siegel zero. https://mathoverflow.net/questions/434583/philosophy-behind-zhangs-2022-preprint-on-the-landau-siegel-zero.

Jireh Loreaux said:

Sure, the port from Lean 3 to Lean 4 is still ongoing, and I'm virtually certain LTE uses things that haven't been ported yet.

Sure. Can you suggest any theorems which is small in size and already proven on Lean 4, I still want to check if AutoGPT gives correct answers , thanks...
Well, read about it. I think it's doing the kind of thing you're interested in, but better because it incorporates feedback from Lean.
